data.meta_description: Posts about Television written by Dennis
data.text:
Spoiler Warning: Beware minor spoilers for some of the titles below.

Although I can scarcely believe Iâ€™m writing these wordsâ€¦ 2024 is officially halfway over! The summer solstice has passed, the nights are getting longer, and before you know it the leaves will be falling from the trees and weâ€™ll be thinking about getting the Christmas decorations out of storage! Maybe thatâ€™s a depressing thought for some of you, but I gotta be honest: I love the autumn and winter seasons!

The last day of June marks the halfway point of the year, and I think that makes it a good opportunity not to look behind, but ahead. In late December Iâ€™ll dish out my annual End-of-Year Awards, but today is about looking forward to some of the entertainment experiences we might enjoy between now and Christmas. Iâ€™ve picked six films, six video games, and six television shows that I think could be fun to watch or play in the second half of 2024.

As always, a couple of caveats! This list is just one personâ€™s subjective opinion, so if I highlight a production that looks just awful to you, or if I miss something that you think is super obviousâ€¦ thatâ€™s okay! There are loads of things to get excited about and I canâ€™t cover all of them. Secondly, with strikes, pandemics, and other possible issues, itâ€™s possible that some or all of these titles will miss their intended release dates or even slip back into 2025. Everything listed below is scheduled for 2024 at time of writing, but things can change!

With all of that out of the way, letâ€™s look ahead to some of the entertainment experiences we might be enjoying between now and New Yearâ€™s Eve.

Films:

I have to be honest: I havenâ€™t seen any brand-new films so far this year! There are a couple on my radar from the first six months of 2024: Civil War, for instance, and the two-part Rebel Moon, but I just havenâ€™t made time for any of them yet. Hopefully thatâ€™ll changeâ€¦ Iâ€™d love to get a review or two written in the weeks ahead!

Film #1:

The Lord of the Rings: War of the Rohirrim

2024 is shaping up to be an interesting year for Tolkien fans. The Rings of Power is returning for its second season, but weâ€™re also getting the first of several brand-new projects: War of the Rohirrim. Set a hundred years before the events of The Hobbit and The Lord of the Rings, War of the Rohirrim will focus on the â€œRiders of Rohanâ€ and the King of Rohan Helm Hammerhand. Helm and his men will defend their kingdomâ€¦ and presumably establish the legendary fortress of Helmâ€™s Deep.

One interesting thing about this film is that itâ€™s animated rather than live-action, and its success could pave the way for more animated Middle-earth projects, perhaps. Director Kenji Kamiyama is well-known in Japan for his work on anime titles like Ghost in the Shell and Eden of the East. As someone who doesnâ€™t know the first thing about animeâ€¦ Iâ€™ll be very curious to see what comes of this fusion of Tolkienâ€™s world with a uniquely Japanese filmmaking style.

Film #2:

Megalopolis

Francis Ford Coppolaâ€™s epic film has been decades in the making, and the legendary director has poured a lot of his time, effort, and talent into creating it â€“ and no small amount of his own money, too. I genuinely donâ€™t know what the result will be; are we going to get a picture comparable to the likes of Coppolaâ€™s own Apocalypse Nowâ€¦ or a truly spectacular flop? Some folks seem to have already decided that Megalopolis will be the latter, but until Iâ€™ve seen it for myself I donâ€™t want to pass judgement!

The film is set against the backdrop of a New York-inspired city having been destroyed, and the attempts to rebuild it being hampered by a corrupt elite. There could be an interesting message there, perhaps, given events out here in the real world. Either way, Iâ€™ll be curious to see what this long-awaited film actually looks like when the dust settles.

Film #3:

Horizon: An American Saga

Parts 1 & 2

Some folks will tell you that the western died a long time agoâ€¦ but I donâ€™t think thatâ€™s really true! There have been fewer westerns produced in recent years than there were at the genreâ€™s peak, but new titles are still making their way to the big screen. Kevin Costnerâ€™s Horizon: An American Saga is one of them â€“ and the first two of a purported four-part series are slated to be released this year. I love a good western, and some recent titles in the space have done very different things, from gritty realism to flipping traditional narrative archetypes on their head.

Horizon: An American Saga is set before and after the American Civil War, and all we really know at this stage is that it will depict different characters and families as they settle the western portion of the United States. There are some good actors in the ensemble cast, including Kevin Costner himself, Avatarâ€™s Sam Worthington, Will Patton, and Michael Rooker from The Walking Dead.

Film #4:

Moana 2

I felt it was a tad unfortunate that the original Moana was released the same year as Zootopia, as the latter film seemed â€“ for a time, anyway â€“ to have really captured the attention of a younger audience! Over time, however, I think Moana has done very well for Disney, and is arguably one of the corporationâ€™s last animated feature films to have been a major success in its own right. Disney has since pivoted to sequels and live-action remakesâ€¦ which is why weâ€™re getting not only Moana 2 but a new adaptation of the original film!

Disneyâ€™s sequels have always struggled with one problem: what comes after â€œhappily ever after?â€ For most of the companyâ€™s animated films, the answer has been â€œnot much,â€ with the resultant pictures going straight-to-video or being worked into Disney Channel series! But Frozen II showed that Disney can do high-quality sequels on the big screenâ€¦ so thereâ€™s hope for Moana 2, at least.

Film #5:

Red One

Santa Claus gets kidnapped? And his chief of security, The Rock, has to rescue him? That sounds like the setup for a film that could be absolutely awfulâ€¦ or maybe brilliant! Truth be told, I love a good Christmas story, and Red One seems to be putting an action-comedy spin on the whole â€œChristmas is in dangerâ€ concept thatâ€™s become a timeless holiday staple.

Red One features a stellar cast, including Chris Evans, J.K. Simmons, and Lucy Liu alongside Dwayne Johnson. A couple of years ago I was hearing talk of the film being the first part of a kind of â€œexpanded universeâ€ of holiday-related films. Not sure if thatâ€™s still going ahead, but Red One could be a fun title regardless. Whether itâ€™ll be the kind of classic that weâ€™ll want to return to at Christmas time every yearâ€¦ Iâ€™m not sure! But you never know.

Film #6:

Wallace and Gromit: Vengeance Most Fowl

The most evil penguin in the world â€“ and one of cinemaâ€™s great villains â€“ is finally returning this Christmas! Vengeance Most Fowl will see the long-awaited return of Feathers McGraw, and he seems set on getting his revenge on those who wronged him all those years ago! Iâ€™m genuinely looking forward to this one â€“ the Wallace and Gromit pictures have all been a ton of fun, and stop-motion with plasticine figures is something genuinely different in an animation landscape overrun by CGI.

As to the plotâ€¦ I confess that Iâ€™m not entirely convinced that returning to a storyline from a previous adventure is the right move. I could certainly have entertained the idea of telling an entirely new story. But Iâ€™m definitely going to be checking out Wallace and Gromitâ€™s latest adventure no matter what!

Television:

The first half of 2024 has seen some interesting TV shows. My current favourite has to be Netflixâ€™s 3 Body Problem, which has belatedly been renewed for two further seasons. I have a review you can find by clicking or tapping here if youâ€™re interested! But thereâ€™s more to come, and the next six months promise some new and exciting programmes to enjoy.

TV Show #1:

Lego Star Wars: Rebuild the Galaxy

Here at Trekking with Dennis, we love and support the Lego Star Wars specials on Disney+! There have been three so far: one Christmas-themed, one Halloween-themed, and one set in the summertime. All have been fantastic, light-hearted takes on Star Warsâ€¦ and given the bitterness and division in the Star Wars fan community, that can be just what we all need to see sometimes!

Rebuild the Galaxy sounds like it will be a time-travelling tale of undoing mistakes and restoring the correct timelineâ€¦ with a few fun alternative ideas about Star Wars in the mix, too. Darth Jar Jar, anyone? Hopefully itâ€™ll be a ton of fun, with Mark Hamill and Ahmed Best joining in to voice their iconic characters.

TV Show #2:

The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power

Season 2

As I said when I took a look at The Rings of Powerâ€™s upcoming second season a few weeks ago, there are reasons to be positive as the series returns after a two-year hiatus. But I also donâ€™t see any kind of reboot or resetting of a series that, in some quarters, has proven to be controversial, which could mean that this incredibly expensive production will continue to struggle to win over both longstanding fans of Middle-earth and a wider audience.

For what itâ€™s worth, I enjoyed what The Rings of Power did. Particularly when the series stepped away from big questions about Sauronâ€™s reign and the shape of the world and told smaller, more character-oriented stories, I felt there were sparks of genius. And I will never not be interested in a high-budget production that expands our understanding of one of the original, foundational fantasy worlds. Maybe The Rings of Power is imperfect, and maybe Season 2 wonâ€™t be the soft reboot that it arguably neededâ€¦ but Iâ€™m still looking forward to it!

TV Show #3:

Phineas and Ferb

Season 5

This one is tentative, but Phineas and Ferbâ€™s return is supposedly still on the schedule for 2024. We donâ€™t have anything official on that, and we havenâ€™t seen any trailers, but it would be great to see Phineas and Ferb back on our screens this autumn or winter. I felt that the TV film Candace Against the Universe was fantastic, and if the writers have found new and exciting storylines for the kids and Dr Doofenshmirtz, we should be in for a fun time!

Phineas and Ferb has become one of my â€œcomfort shows,â€ and I often drift back to it on days when Iâ€™m struggling with my mental health. From my perspective, Iâ€™m really happy at the prospect of getting some new adventures with Phineas, Ferb, Perry the Platypus, and the rest of the gang. The challenge for any revived or renewed series is finding a way to recapture the magic of those earlier seasonsâ€¦ and finding a better justification for a return than â€œbecause money.â€ Iâ€™m crossing my fingersâ€¦ but Iâ€™m more than happy to wait until 2025 or even 2026 if it means better episodes and stories.

TV Show #4:

Those About To Die

Those About To Die is a series focusing on gladiators in the Roman Empire. It will star Anthony Hopkins as the Roman Emperorâ€¦ and thatâ€™s about all I know at this stage! The trailer left me with echoes of Game of Thrones (and not just because of the presence of actor Iwan Rheon) with themes of politicking, backstabbing, and control of the Empire all seemingly in play.

There hasnâ€™t been a big-budget production set in ancient Rome for quite some time, so Iâ€™ll be curious to see what director Roland Emmerich can do with this unique setting. Hopefully weâ€™ll get some action and excitement at the very least!

TV Show #5:

Star Trek: Lower Decks

Season 5

I really need to climb out of my Star Trek doldrums and watch Season 4 of Lower Decks before I can get too excited about Season 5! Unfortunately, this is set to be the final outing for Mariner, Boimler, and the rest of the crew of the Cerritos, as Paramount cancelled the series earlier this year. Hopefully weâ€™ll get a fitting send-off for an enjoyable series and cast of characters.

Lower Decks has been an interesting experiment for the Star Trek franchise â€“ one that would probably have worked better were it not drowned out, at times, by too many other Star Trek productions on our screens all at once. But I hope this wonâ€™t be the end for the franchiseâ€™s flirtation with animation â€“ itâ€™s a format that has worked well. Lower Decks also took Star Trek back to an older, more episodic style of storytelling, which is something I continue to appreciate.

TV Show #6:

Leonardo da Vinci

Iâ€™ve been a big fan of Ken Burnsâ€™ work for a long time, and Leonardo da Vinci will be the acclaimed filmmakerâ€™s first documentary about a non-American subject. Da Vinci led a fascinating life, and I have no doubt that weâ€™ll all learn a lot about the legendary scientist and artist through this new two-part miniseries.

Ken Burns has a unique style that makes his documentaries for PBS really stand out, so Iâ€™m looking forward to seeing what his take will be on one of the greatest polymaths of the Renaissance era.

Video Games:

Donâ€™t tell anyone, but I think I already know what my â€œgame of the yearâ€ will be when I hand out some imaginary statuettes in December! Little Kitty, Big City is an adorable and incredibly fun title, but Iâ€™ve also had fun in the first half of 2024 playing EA Sports PGA Tourâ€¦ a golf game. Thereâ€™s a lot more to come before Christmas rolls around, though!

Video Game #1:

Star Wars: Outlaws

One of the things Iâ€™ve argued that Star Wars needs to do is step away from the Jedi, Sith, and the Force and show us more about how the regular citizens of the galaxy live. Outlaws seems poised to do just that, focusing on the criminal underworld that weâ€™ve caught glimpses of in other productions. This is, however, a Ubisoft open-world title â€“ and Ubisoftâ€™s particular formula for making games like that is arguably played out at this point. Not to mention there are about a dozen different â€œeditionsâ€ of the game, all of which offer some kind of exclusive content and cost a lot more money!

I wouldnâ€™t say that I have sky-high expectations for Outlaws, and having come away from last yearâ€™s Jedi: Survivor feeling pretty disappointed, this is a game I admit that I have reservations about. If it all comes together, though, I think we could finally get that personal Han Solo-inspired adventure that many Star Wars fans â€“ myself included â€“ have been interested in for a long time. Just pleaseâ€¦ donâ€™t make protagonist Kay Vess another â€œsecret Jedi in disguise!â€

Video Game #2:

Life By You

I was all ready to tell you about how genuinely excited I was at the prospect of a proper competitor to The Simsâ€¦ only to belatedly learn that publisher Paradox cancelled Life By You just months before it was scheduled to be released. Thatâ€™s disappointing â€“ not only for those of us who mightâ€™ve wanted to play it, but for the developers whoâ€™d been working on it for over five years at this point.

The Sims has had this genre almost all to itself for a long time, and the result has been a game drowning in expensive add-ons and â€œcontent packs.â€ Life By You could, perhaps, have shaken up a stale genre and done things differently. Weâ€™ll never know what might have been.

Video Game #3:

Star Trucker

Euro Truck Simulator meets science fiction! If that sounds like fun to you, maybe youâ€™ll like Star Trucker. As the name suggests, itâ€™s a game about piloting â€“ or should that be driving? â€“ cargo ships in a sci-fi setting. It looks like a ton of fun; the kind of â€œcozy gameâ€ that I can find myself losing hours of my life playing!

Star Trucker hadnâ€™t been on my radar at all until I saw it at Xboxâ€™s Summer Showcase event a few weeks ago, but now Iâ€™m definitely curious to give it a go. Iâ€™ve played a fair amount of games like Euro Truck Simulator and Train Simulator, and taking that kind of gameplay to a weirder outer space setting seems like it could be a blast.

Video Game #4:

Indiana Jones and the Great Circle

I have to be honest with you: Iâ€™m not sure about this one. Something about the marketing material for Indiana Jones and the Great Circle is just rubbing me the wrong way, and the gameâ€™s visuals feel decidedly underwhelming, too. Still, as a child of the â€™80s I feel a strong connection with the Indiana Jones seriesâ€¦ and after recent films have failed to impress, surely Indy is overdue for a hit?

The likes of Tomb Raider and Uncharted have shown that video games can do incredibly well with these kinds of historical mystery-adventures, so it could be great to give the granddaddy of the genre one more chance in the video game realm. Maybe, just maybe, Iâ€™m wrong about this one and Indiana Jones and the Great Circle will be the kind of rip-roaring adventure Iâ€™m looking for. Fingers crossed, eh?

Video Game #5:

Super Mario Party Jamboree

Iâ€™ve had a soft spot for the Mario Party series since I played the first entry on the Nintendo 64 way back when! Itâ€™s great to see that Nintendo is keeping this fun, family-friendly party series around, and even more so to see that a couple of game boards from those early N64 titles are being recreated this time around. It looks like there will be plenty of fun to be had for Mario and the gang!

As the Nintendo Switch begins to wind down and rumors of a new console have even been confirmed by Nintendo, Super Mario Party Jamboree could end up being one of the last big first-party titles created for the machine. With more than 100 mini-games, seven game boards, and a robust online mode, it seems like itâ€™ll be a great send-off for the Switch.

Video Game #6:

Tales of the Shire

Tales of the Shire feels like it could be The Hobbit meets Animal Crossing! Pitched as a life sim set in the world of Tolkienâ€™s Middle-earth, it looks like there will be a lot of customisation for both player characters and their Hobbit-holes, and a lot of fun, cozy gameplay to get stuck into.

Thereâ€™s a lot of Middle-earth content on the way, including several new films that were announced earlier in 2024. Thereâ€™s definitely space for a title like Tales of the Shireâ€¦ letâ€™s just hope it fares better than Gollum did last year!

So thatâ€™s it!

Weâ€™ve taken a look at a handful of films, TV series, and video games that I think are worth keeping an eye on as the second half of 2024 gets underway. Though it scarcely seems like any time has passed since we were taking down the last of the Christmas ornaments (and I still have an uneaten Christmas pudding in my cupboard), timeâ€™s marching on, and the autumn and winter seasons will be upon us before too long!

I hope Iâ€™ve given you an idea or two, at any rate. There are plenty of interesting-sounding titles that didnâ€™t make the list this time around, and as I noted just last year, some of my favourite entertainment experiences came out of nowhere and completely surprised me! So I hope there will be some unexpected titles in the mix in the second half of 2024, too.

As the summer season gets underway, I wish you all the best.

All titles discussed above are the copyright of their respective owner, distributor, studio, broadcaster, publisher, etc. Some images and promotional artwork courtesy of IMDB and IGDB. This article contains the thoughts and opinions of one person only and is not intended to cause any offence.

Spoiler Warning: Spoilers may be present for some of the franchises/properties discussed below.

There are a handful of â€œbig questionsâ€ that define oneâ€™s place in geekdom â€“ and today itâ€™s my turn to answer some of them!

I thought it could be a bit of fun to consider some of the biggest questions that geeks like us have to wrangle with. Which fictional character is stronger? Which gaming platform is the best? These questions are contentious, especially here on the interweb â€“ but I hope youâ€™ll engage with this piece in the spirit of light-hearted fun! Thatâ€™s how Iâ€™m choosing to present my answers, in any case.

As I always like to say, nothing weâ€™re going to talk about today is in any way â€œobjective!â€ These are my wholly subjective takes on questions that are intended to evoke strong reactions, so I hope youâ€™ll keep that in mind! Although Iâ€™ve said that these are ten of the â€œbiggestâ€ geeky questions, Iâ€™m sure you can think of others â€“ so this is by no means a definitive list.

Iâ€™ve considered myself a geek â€“ and been considered a geek by others â€“ for basically my whole life. As a kid and a teenager, I moved in nerdy circles and friend groups where the likes of fantasy, sci-fi, horror, and video games were frequent topics of conversation. And in the â€™80s and â€™90s, those things were far less â€œmainstreamâ€ than they are nowadays! Itâ€™s actually been really cool to see the likes of The Lord of the Rings, Star Wars, and Marvel become some of the biggest entertainment properties on the planet â€“ as well as the explosion in popularity of video games. When I was at school, and even into my young adulthood, admitting to being interested in those kinds of things could lead to mockery and even bullying!

For these questions today, Iâ€™ve set myself the rule of providing an actual answer â€“ no cop-out, fence-sitting, â€œI like both equallyâ€ answers here! As Iâ€™ve already said, all of this is just one personâ€™s opinion â€“ and at the end of the day, this is supposed to just be for fun. So please try not to take it too seriously; none of this is worth getting into an argument over!

With the introduction out of the way, letâ€™s answer some tough geeky questions!

Question #1:

Whoâ€™s the best Doctor?

Doctor Who

I donâ€™t really remember watching much Doctor Who as a kid. The original incarnation of the long-running BBC sci-fi series was coming to an end when I was younger, and by the time I was getting interested in the genre, it was Star Trek: The Next Generation that really captured my imagination. As a result, Iâ€™m going to exclude all of the pre-2005 Doctors from consideration; I simply havenâ€™t seen enough of any of them to really have a favourite.

Of the Doctors that have been part of the revived series, the Twelfth â€“ played by Peter Capaldi â€“ is my favouriteâ€¦ but with a big caveat! Capaldi gave the best individual performance as the Doctor in the role â€“ hands down. No disrespect meant to any of the othersâ€¦ but I donâ€™t think itâ€™s even close. Heâ€™s a performer with exactly the right style, look, and gravitas â€“ and in my view, he played the role absolutely perfectly. Thatâ€™s why I didnâ€™t hesitate when it came to naming him as my favourite!

But thereâ€™s a catch, as I said. Capaldiâ€™s seasons as the Doctor â€“ Seasons 8 through 10 of the post-2005 series â€“ were almost universally terrible. There was one decent companion (Bill, played by Pearl Mackie) but her character was treated almost as an afterthought and she met a stupid and unsatisfying end. There were hardly any decent villains or antagonists, no truly standout episodes, and really very few memorable moments at all. In fact, Capaldiâ€™s tenure as the Doctor marked a significant decline in Doctor Whoâ€™s qualityâ€¦ and the series doesnâ€™t seem to have recovered.

In terms of the best seasons of the revived Doctor Who, Iâ€™d have to give the award â€“ somewhat begrudgingly â€“ to Seasons 2 through 4, which starred David Tennant in the title role. The quality of the stories produced at that time was so much higher, with some truly outstanding adventures in the mix. If only there was some way to go back in time and combine Capaldiâ€™s performance with Tennantâ€™s storylines. Whereâ€™s a Tardis when you need one, eh?

Question #2:

Who would win in a fight: Batman or Superman?

DC Comics

Uh, this one should be obvious. Itâ€™s Superman, right? It has to be â€“ if you gave any other answer then I donâ€™t think youâ€™ve been paying attention! Who would win in a fight between an overpowered demigod and a billionaire with some expensive gadgets? Yeahâ€¦ the demigod is gonna win this one. He could launch Batman into the sun, punch him so hard that every bone in his body would shatter, use his heat-vision on him from half a mile awayâ€¦ the list of ways in which Superman could not just defeat but murder and utterly annihilate Batman is nearly endless!

Superman is, I would argue, increasingly difficult to depict in film because of how blatantly overpowered he is. If you read my review of Zack Snyderâ€™s Justice League a couple of years ago, you might remember me saying that the film flopped around, desperately trying to find a way to include the rest of its cast of superheroesâ€¦ but to no avail. There was no getting away from the simple fact that Superman could do it all single-handedly without even breaking a sweat.

At the time the character of Superman was first created, all the way back in 1938, it wasnâ€™t a problem. In fact, creating an â€œall-round, all-American heroâ€ for comic books aimed at children was exactly the point. Superman is textbook escapism â€“ heâ€™s the perfect hero archetype that can do it all. In context, Superman works, and when all you want is a â€œgood guyâ€ to save the day and stop the evil villains, heâ€™s perfect for the part.

But any story that puts Superman in genuine danger has to come up with a reason why. The manâ€™s basically invincible, save for the mysterious crystal known as kryptonite, and I think at least some of Supermanâ€™s big-screen and small-screen adventures suffer as a result of that. But to get back on topic: Superman would win in a fight, and heâ€™d win incredibly quickly and incredibly easily!

Question #3:

Console or PC?

In the early â€™90s, the first home console I ever owned was a Super Nintendo. From then on, all the way through to the middle of the last decade, console was my preference. I liked the pick-up-and-play nature of consoles, with no need to check system requirements or fiddle with settings to just get a game running. The underpowered PCs that I had in the â€™90s werenâ€™t much good for gaming, so I think thatâ€™s part of it, too. But you have to also remember that, for a long time, consoles were just better in terms of performance â€“ and especially in terms of value â€“ than PC.

But nowadays Iâ€™m firmly on Team PC! I built my own PC for the first time a couple of years ago, and prior to that I had a moderately-priced â€œgamingâ€ PC. Since about the middle of the 2010s, PC has been my platform of choice for practically everything. I will consider picking up Nintendoâ€™s next machine when itâ€™s ready, but my Nintendo Switch has been gathering dust since I stopped playing Animal Crossing and Mario Kart 8â€¦ so Iâ€™m not sure how great of an investment thatâ€™ll really be!

PC offers the best of both worlds. Wanna play an in-depth strategy game or city-builder with loads of options and menus that really need a mouse and keyboard to navigate? PC can do that. Wanna plug in a modern control pad to play a third-person adventure title? PC can do that too. Wanna install a virtual machine and play games from the Windows 95 era? PC can do that! Wanna emulate every console from the Atari 2600 to the Dreamcast and play games that are out-of-print everywhere? PC can do that too!

With Game Pass bringing a lot of new titles to PC on launch day, and with Sony even porting over some of its previously-exclusive titles too, PC really feels like the place to be. Itâ€™s a lot more expensive to get started with â€“ and thatâ€™s still a massive point in favour of consoles for players on a budget. But once that initial expense is out of the way, the abundance of sales on platforms like Steam means that a lot of titles â€“ even newer ones â€“ can be picked up at a discount. Iâ€™m really happy with my PC as my main gaming platform, and I doubt Iâ€™ll be picking up an Xbox or PlayStation this generation.

Question #4:

What would be the best fictional world to live in?

There are loads of absolutely awful answers that people give to this question! Whoâ€™d want to live in Star Warsâ€™ fascist-corporate dystopia, for example, which seems absolutely terrible for anyone not blessed with space magic? Or any fantasy setting with a medieval level of technology? Sure, you might have a magic elf as your buddyâ€¦ but if thereâ€™s no central heating, antibiotics, or flushing toiletsâ€¦ youâ€™re gonna have a bad time!

My pick is simple: Star Trekâ€™s 24th Century. There are things to worry about, sure: the Borg, the Cardassians, and the Klingons to name but a few threats! But there are so many wonderful inventions and technologies that would make life so much better. For me, as someone with disabilities, the idea of some or all of my health issues being cured is perhaps the biggest â€“ but there are plenty of others, too.

Star Trek does not depict, as some have tried to claim, a â€œcommunist utopia.â€ As we see on multiple occasions throughout the franchise, private property still exists, and people have a great deal of freedom and autonomy. Star Trekâ€™s future could be more accurately described as a post-scarcity society â€“ one in which technological improvements have brought unlimited power generation, food, and other resources to the people.

There are some dark spots in Star Trekâ€™s future â€“ but these tend to be places outside of or separate from the Federation. Assuming I could live somewhere in the Federation, and have access to replicators, warp drive, weather-controlling satellites, and Starfleet for defenceâ€¦ I think it would be bliss! And so much better than anywhere else I can think of.

Question #5:

Martin or Tolkien?

I donâ€™t need to think too long about this one! JRR Tolkien is, for me, one of the greatest authors of all-time. George RR Martin, in contrast, canâ€™t even finish his own story, and seems far too easily distracted by other projects â€“ including writing TV episodes and working on video games. And câ€™monâ€¦ he literally copied the â€œRRâ€ part of Tolkienâ€™s name for his own pen name!

Jokes aside, I think both writers are pretty great. Tolkien could be, in places, a little too black-and-white with his protagonists and antagonists, with the goodies being pure and virtuous and the villains being corrupt and evil. Martinâ€™s work deliberately upends many of those notions, and he places imperfect and even selfish characters at the heart of his stories. Some of George RR Martinâ€™s characters feel more nuanced â€“ and dare I say more human â€“ than Tolkienâ€™s.

But Tolkien was a pioneer, writing the first modern fantasy epic. Martin, and countless other writers, are simply following in his footsteps. While Martinâ€™s work is hardly derivative, some of the choices he makes in his writing are a reaction to the way Tolkienâ€™s worlds and characters were set up. Itâ€™s impossible to critique A Song of Ice and Fire without making multiple references to Tolkien â€“ whereas Tolkienâ€™s work has always stood on its own two feet.

I would love it if George RR Martin would finish his magnum opus, but as time passes I feel less and less sure that heâ€™s even interested in doing so. Now that Game of Thrones has finished its run on television, and Martin has seen the overwhelmingly negative reaction to its ending â€“ which will have contained at least some elements that he planned to include in the remaining books â€“ I just donâ€™t get the impression that his heart is in it in the same way it was a few years ago. Tolkienâ€™s work, in contrast, is complete and has been for decades â€“ and people are still interested in new adaptations.

Question #6:

Whoâ€™s the best Star Trek captain?

Iâ€™ve always struggled with this question. Spoiler Warning: There are spoilers ahead for the Fallout TV series and minor spoilers for several of the Fallout video games.

Having played a couple of the games, Iâ€™m no stranger to the world of Fallout â€“ but Iâ€™m not exactly a super-fan of the franchise, either. The showâ€™s writing team had also been working with Bethesda Game Studios â€“ developers of the more recent Fallout titles â€“ and again that seemed like something positive as this unique setting was adapted for a brand-new medium.

I came away from Fallout feeling moderately impressed â€“ but by no means blown away. There were some great charactersâ€¦ and one so cringeworthy that I literally fast-forwarded through several of their scenes. I also think it was a mistake to dump the entire season at once instead of releasing episodes week-by-week as Amazon Prime Video usually does.

Fallout, for me, was a show that needed room to breathe. I needed to let the events of each episode settle before racing ahead to the next â€“ and with social media awash with spoilers within literally hours of the showâ€™s arrival on Amazon Prime Video, I felt a strange kind of pressure to binge more episodes than I wanted to. If Fallout released its episodes weekly, the show wouldâ€™ve been part of our collective cultural conversation for a couple of months. As it is, Fallout was already beginning to disappear just days after its premiere.

One day weâ€™ll have to talk in more depth about binge-watch culture and the pros and cons of releasing brand-new television shows this way. But for now, I think Iâ€™ve made my point about how Fallout was harmed by this strange and unexpected decision.

When adapting a video game for a new medium, one of the big challenges that writers and designers face is how to include some of the gameâ€™s interactive elements. One thing that has been alluded to many times in the Fallout video games, but never directly shown, was the state of the world prior to the nuclear war. As a final point on Vault-Tec: Iâ€™d be remiss if I didnâ€™t mention how a critique of mega-corporations and how unethical they are is beyond ironic coming from the likes of Amazon! One of the biggest multinationals on the planet putting out this kind of over-the-top depiction of the worst kind of shady corporatism is truly hilarious, and the irony of that wasnâ€™t lost on me.

In typical streaming TV style, Falloutâ€™s character groupings were modelled on the likes of Game of Thrones: different sets of characters start out in different places, but come together as the story progresses. Aside from causing a little tension for Cooper/the Ghoul at the midpoint of the story, it wasnâ€™t really explained or expanded upon, and didnâ€™t serve much of a narrative function.

At the end of the day, Fallout kept my attention well enough. I can be pretty brutal about switching off a series if Iâ€™m not enjoying it or if it isnâ€™t holding my interest, and despite some issues, Fallout told a story that I was content to follow to its conclusion. Iâ€™m pleased to hear that the series has already been renewed for a second season, and I hope that production can re-start quickly so that it can be broadcast within twelve months or so. Waiting too long in between short seasons â€“ especially for a show that dropped all of its episodes at once â€“ can cause issues!

I doubt that Iâ€™ll be calling Fallout one of the best shows of the year, but it was interesting enough for what it was. There were some great acting performances, high production values, and a connected story that was generally fun enough and worth following. As some of Falloutâ€™s mysteries were unravelled I was genuinely surprised, and the series was kept on track by several grounded and enjoyable characters.

There were a couple of places where visual effects or physical props fell short, but nothing especially egregious leapt out to ruin my sense of immersion in Falloutâ€™s post-nuclear world. There were moments of intrigue, action, and excitement that propelled the story forward, and if my biggest complaint is â€œI wouldâ€™ve liked to see a couple more episodes,â€ because some of the fun storylines and interesting characters needed a bit more time on screenâ€¦ well, thatâ€™s not the worst thing in the world, is it?

I didnâ€™t need to pick up a new subscription for Fallout as Iâ€™m already signed up to Amazon Prime. Iâ€™m not sure it would be worth signing up for on its own merit â€“ unless youâ€™re a super-fan of the Fallout series or post-apocalyptic stories in general â€“ but considering I got it as part of a subscription that I already have, I guess I canâ€™t complain too much! Fallout was imperfect, but it was a solid start for what could be a multi-season story that should only grow and improve from here.

The first part of this review is free from major story spoilers. The end of the spoiler-free section is clearly marked.

Right off the bat, I ought to tell you two things. First, Iâ€™ve never read The Three-Body Problem by Liu Cixin, nor either of its sequels. Iâ€™d seen the barest of outlines of the premise when I looked into it a couple of years ago â€“ after hearing that Netflix had greenlit this adaptation â€“ but I didnâ€™t track down and read a copy. To be honestâ€¦ it seemed like it might be a bit weighty and dense for my reading tastes! As a result, Iâ€™m not going to be comparing 3 Body Problem to its source material â€“ because Iâ€™m totally unfamiliar with that source material. I know there have been some alterations, with several characters being merged and ethnicities being changed to take a Chinese story and make it multi-racial and multi-cultural, but thatâ€™s really the extent of my knowledge of the changes that Netflix made with its adaptation.

Secondly, regular readers might recall that I didnâ€™t like the final season of Game of Thrones. Why is that relevant? Because the executive producers/showrunners of 3 Body Problem are none other than David Benioff and DB Weiss â€“ who helmed Game of Thrones for its entire eight-season run. I think Iâ€™m right in saying that 3 Body Problem is Benioff and Weissâ€™ second project since Game of Thrones ended, but its the first that Iâ€™ve come across â€“ and arguably the first big project since that series ended its run back in 2019.

Iâ€™ve felt for a long time that Benioff and Weiss did exceptionally well at adapting a complicated series of novels for the small screen â€“ so there was hope for their treatment of 3 Body Problem. Where they went off the rails, I would argue, and where their particular skillset was not as useful, was in writing their own narrative threads and picking up a half-complete story. Nobody couldâ€™ve known back in 2008, when Game of Thrones first entered pre-production, that the novels upon which it was based wouldnâ€™t be finished in time and that the TV series would end up â€œovertakingâ€ the books. But unfortunately, Benioff and Weiss were left to pick up the pieces â€“ and came up short.

But thatâ€™s enough about Game of Thrones for now! All of this is to say that, when dealing with a complete novel trilogy, I felt that there was the potential to see Benioff and Weiss shine once more; to put their unique skills to use on an adaptation of a fully-complete story. And, based on the first season of 3 Body Problem, I think I was right about that.

So hereâ€™s the headline: I liked 3 Body Problem. It was exceptionally well-paced with some incredible acting performances, even from stars that I wasnâ€™t particularly keen to see included. Its narrative was gripping; truly well-written sci-fi with a complicated yet enthralling underlying premise. Characters behaved in ways that felt genuine and human, something that can sometimes get lost in stories about higher dimensions, aliens, and interstellar communication.

Visual effects werenâ€™t perfect, and I felt there were a few moments of the dreaded â€œuncanny valleyâ€ creeping into 3 Body Problem. However, when the action focused on characters up close, set designs, costumes, and props all looked great, and many smaller CGI/animated moments looked solid. When compared to other flagship series in the sci-fi/thriller spaces, 3 Body Problem was probably about on par in terms of animation â€“ and perhaps a cut above when it came to physical sets and props.

3 Body Problem dipped its toes in narrative arcs that looked at religious communities and cults, conspiracy theories, alien races, cross-species communication, and much more. The core group of characters felt well-rounded, and the way in which they interacted with these often strange and confusing storylines went a long way to making the whole thing work and feel relatable. Although much of the action focused on scientists who are far more intelligent than I am, I still found myself relating to them and seeing this twisted version of our own world through their eyes. More than once I caught myself wondering how I wouldâ€™ve reacted, or how I wouldâ€™ve chosen to act if I were in their shoes â€“ and to me, thatâ€™s great storytelling!

There were a few lines of dialogue that were either clunkily overladen with exposition or that made me roll my eyes, but for the most part the series did exceptionally well in that regard. Taking several complicated concepts from the realm of theoretical physics and making them understandable for the layperson is no mean feat â€“ but I came away from every episode feeling like I understood what was going on, where the sources of tension and drama were, and how it was impacting our characters and the world around them. Obviously 3 Body Problem isnâ€™t a physics class, and I donâ€™t want to pat myself on the back and pretend that I somehow comprehend something that other viewers wouldnâ€™t! But I want to draw attention to the very real successes that the series had in making its dense topics work in this fictional setting.

The only real concern I have about 3 Body Problem is this: at time of writing, it hasnâ€™t been renewed for a second season. The first season didnâ€™t complete the story, so it needs at least one or realistically two or three more seasons to adapt the remaining books in the series and bring everything to a satisfying conclusion. Iâ€™m sure that the production team and actors will be happy to make the rest of the story â€“ but right now, the spectre of cancellation is hanging over the series. Netflix has a disappointing track record in this area, with a number of popular and high-profile series being cancelled after a single season. I truly hope that 3 Body Problem wonâ€™t join them in the growing Netflix graveyard.

Iâ€™ve also made the point before about long breaks in between short seasons. 3 Body Problem ran to eight episodes â€“ which is increasingly typical for a flagship made-for-streaming series these days. With Netflix still uncommitted to a second season, it will take time to re-start production, and that could easily lead to a two-year wait for Season 2. Thatâ€™s not great, in my opinion, and while I obviously want to see the series continue and finish telling the compelling story it set up, there are issues that arise when any story disappears for years at a time.

So I think Iâ€™ve covered as much as I can without digging into specific story threads and character moments. I donâ€™t put numbers out of ten or star ratings out of five on my reviews, but if you want to know whether or not I recommend 3 Body Problem, the answer is a resounding â€œyes.â€ Definitely give it a watch if you have access to Netflix, and itâ€™s probably even worth picking up a monthâ€™s worth of Netflix to give it a watch if, like me, youâ€™re being a bit more careful with subscriptions in the current economic climate. Thatâ€™s what I did, at any rate!

What Iâ€™ll do now is talk in a bit more detail about characters and storylines â€“ right up to the end of the season. So if you havenâ€™t seen 3 Body Problem yet and you donâ€™t want to have it spoiled, this is your opportunity to jump ship! But I hope youâ€™ll come back to see what I have to say after youâ€™re done watching all eight episodes.

This is the end of the spoiler-free section of this review. There will be spoilers for 3 Body Problem from this point forwards â€“ including twists, character arcs, and the way the season ended.

There are some producers and writers who love to collaborate with the same actors over and over again. Tim Burton and Johnny Depp, John Ford and John Wayne, and JJ Abrams and Simon Pegg all come to mind as well-known partners across multiple productions. But I confess that I was a little surprised (and disappointed) to see Benioff and Weiss pick three prolific former Game of Thrones cast members to star in 3 Body Problem. Going into the series, I was especially cautious about John Bradley taking on a main role â€“ but also worried about the potential for Liam Cunningham and Johnathan Pryce to overshadow or get in the way of the scenes they were in.

None of these three had any on-screen interaction, which I think is actually a good thing. Pryce is an actor whoâ€™s played many different roles over the years, and while his â€œreligious nutâ€ character in 3 Body Problem had echoes of his starring role in Game of Thrones, it wasnâ€™t enough to overshadow it as Iâ€™d feared. Cunningham took on a very different role as the leader of the shadowy MI5/CIA-inspired organisation, and thoroughly excelled.

John Bradley was the actor I had the most concerns about going into 3 Body Problem, and while I wouldnâ€™t say that he was â€œmiscastâ€ in that roleâ€¦ I think thereâ€™s a degree of favouritism from the producers there. Bradleyâ€™s performance was solid enough, but Rooney was arguably the least-convincing of the main characters â€“ meaning his relatively early demise was probably to the seriesâ€™ overall benefit.

Ever since she first appeared as Keiko Oâ€™Brien in Star Trek: The Next Generation, I felt that Rosalind Chao had the ability to play a starring role. We saw a bit of that in Deep Space Nine, with episodes like In The Hands of the Prophets that gave Keiko a central role in the plot. Chao did not disappoint in 3 Body Problem, taking on the challenging role of an elder Ye Wenjie. Ye was the one who contacted the San-Ti, and who â€œinvitedâ€ them to come to Earth, and later had to come to terms with what that might mean for herself and for humanity. The younger version of the character seemed to be steadfast and resolute in her decision, but as time passed â€“ and especially after the San-Ti had abandoned her and her followers to their gruesome fates â€“ Ye was left alone with the weight of what she had done.

Itâ€™s hard to imagine an actor better-placed to play that role, and Rosalind Chao excelled. The scene in which Ye Wenjie was revealed as the true leader of the San-Ti worshippers was genuinely breathtaking, and her scenes in a holding cell as she at first resisted sharing what she knew, then came to terms with the San-Ti abandoning her and her fellow cultists, was riveting. Yeâ€™s final realisation that she had single-handedly inflicted this catastrophe on all of humankind was shattering for her â€“ and Rosalind Chao brought every bit of that process to life in gut-wrenching fashion.

One thing that modern sci-fi does exceptionally well is emphasising just how different an alien race could be from humanity. Weâ€™re used to seeing prosthetic foreheads on aliens in Star Trek, or the human-sized, bipedal aliens present in the Star Wars galaxy, but the reality of alien life â€“ assuming it exists out there in the cosmos somewhere â€“ is likely going to be very different! The Expanse showed us the â€œprotomolecule,â€ and that was a really clever and fun idea. And in 3 Body Problem weâ€™re introduced to the San-Ti.

I would love to know what the San-Ti really look like. Are they giant space bears? Insectoid? Perhaps some kind of multi-legged amphibian? The fact that they went unseen for the entirety of 3 Body Problem â€“ being represented only by deliberately humanoid virtual avatars â€“ was a hugely positive thing as it keeps the mystery going! Iâ€™m not sure whether their true form gets revealed in one of the subsequent novels, but I kind of hope that they remain a mystery. Keeping only a single humanoid avatar (and human cultists) worked exceptionally well. And I think the series might lose something significant if the San-Tiâ€™s true form were revealed too soon!

The titular â€œthree-body problemâ€ is something that, I have to confess, my neanderthal brain is struggling with. A planet orbiting three stars is affected by the gravity of all three â€“ but predicting its path becomes impossible beyond a certain point. Thatâ€™s my ridiculously oversimplified understandingâ€¦ but hereâ€™s what I donâ€™t get. If the planetâ€™s position can be predicted at all, whatâ€™s to stop someone clever from making prediction atop prediction, until theyâ€™ve plotted the planetâ€™s course over centuries or millennia? Itâ€™s something to do with â€œchaos theory,â€ isnâ€™t it? This stuff is way above my intellectual level! But itâ€™s to the credit of 3 Body Problem that I came away with even that basic of an understanding of such a complex topic.

Having two timelines on the go at once â€“ a â€œpresent dayâ€ and â€œflashbackâ€ â€“ seems to be in vogue in made-for-streaming TV at the moment, but itâ€™s one element of 3 Body Problem that worked well. We started with young Ye Wenjie in the 1960s, and then jumped ahead to see the main plot of the series beginning to unfold. But there were mysteries left in the past that the story would dip back into at key moments, and these two timelines came together to tell a single, cohesive story.

There were some brutal moments in the flashback timeline, right from 3 Body Problemâ€™s premiere episode. Iâ€™m not especially familiar with the history of China and its cultural revolution, but from what I can tell, these kinds of â€œstruggle sessionsâ€ were commonplace during the Mao regime. Seeing one unfold in such brutal fashion was pretty hard-hitting, and while the series didnâ€™t spend a lot of time on this, the themes of authoritarianism and later environmentalism as driving forces motivating Ye, Evans, and other characters were an important part of the way the story was constructed.

Despite great performances by Jonathan Pryce and Ben Schnetzer (as older and younger versions of the character respectively), Mike Evans is perhaps a character who needed a bit more screen time. I found the devotion to the â€œLordâ€ to be suitably creepy â€“ and reminiscent of more than one real-world cult â€“ but Evansâ€™ transformation from wide-eyed environmental activist to oil company executive seemed pretty abrupt. And there wasnâ€™t a lot in the flashback sequences that I felt really informed his steadfast devotion; why had he taken to worshipping the San-Ti so fervently?

And while weâ€™re nitpicking: how had the San-Ti been communicating for (presumably) years or decades with Evans and his followers, placed spies on Earthâ€¦ but didnâ€™t understand the difference between fiction and truth, nor understand how humans are capable of lying? It seems like something they shouldâ€™ve figured out a long time ago, but they didnâ€™t until just the right moment for other narrative beats to play out. Itâ€™s not the worst contrivance in the worldâ€¦ and we could certainly make the case that itâ€™s just another example of how truly different and â€œalienâ€ the San-Ti are in their way of thinking. But as a story beatâ€¦ it was perhaps the biggest point at which I felt the series couldâ€™ve benefitted from another couple of episodes.

One thing I wasnâ€™t expecting in a sci-fi series like 3 Body Problem was a realistic depiction of someone grappling with a terminal illness â€“ but through the character of Will, the show delivered precisely that. Willâ€™s storyline was incredibly emotional as he came to terms with the ending of his life, his regrets, and the things heâ€™d left unsaid. I couldâ€™ve happily spent eight episodes just with Will and his friends â€“ without any of the sci-fi shenanigans going on in the background. Thatâ€™s how powerful I found those sequences to be. Iâ€™m not terminally ill, but I have health issues that I have to live with every day â€“ and I found Will a truly relatable character as he saw his health decline.

There was, of course, a narrative pay-off to Willâ€™s cancer diagnosis, and I liked the way in which 3 Body Problem tied all of its characters and story arcs together. Will seemed to be disconnected from the main storyline of the series much of the time, talking to the other main characters but not really involved with the plan to defend against the San-Ti. Not until the last moment! Willâ€™s sacrifice and the revelation that the mission was a failure was genuinely heartbreaking, especially when all seemed to be going to plan.

Along with Will was the character of Saul, played by Jovan Adepo. I really enjoyed Adepoâ€™s performance, as he brought the character to life and made him feel relatable and real. Starting as a junior researcher, Saulâ€™s story took him through the San-Ti plot to become appointed as one of the â€œWallfacersâ€ â€“ a unique kind of defender of Earth. The fact that he didnâ€™t want the role was also a really relatable moment; he felt heâ€™d been plucked from obscurity and given an impossible task. Thereâ€™s a kind of wish-fulfilment fantasy in this kind of storyline; who among us hasnâ€™t wanted, even just for a moment in the back of our minds, for someone to come along and whisk us away on an adventure, or to be told that weâ€™re being appointed as one of the saviours of all humanity?

Rounding out the main characters were Auggie, Jin, and Raj. I liked how the story began with Auggieâ€™s nano-fibre start-up and then, after seeming to move away from that, brought it back in spectacular fashion. That was one of the moments where I felt every piece of this story had been carefully planned, with characters and storylines being built up with purpose. Jin was perhaps the most emotional of the main characters â€“ though thereâ€™s competition for that title! She served as our point-of-view character at several key moments, and seeing some of these events unfold from her perspective elevated them.

Raj was arguably the least-developed of the main characters; he served a narrative function but didnâ€™t really get enough screen time to really shine â€“ nor did he get any independent storylines. He was tied to either Jinâ€™s story or the showâ€™s main storyline, and in those capacities he helped move things along without really breaking out on his own. Any story has characters like this, I suppose, and itâ€™s not really a criticism as much as an observation.

The depiction of Wadeâ€™s organisation â€“ a three-letter acronym that I honestly couldnâ€™t remember off the top of my head â€“ as being almost everywhere, knowing almost everything felt like a bit of a stretch. As a commentary on government agencies that spy on or observe their citizens I think it couldâ€™ve been interesting, perhaps even making a comparison with the â€œsecret policeâ€ of Maoist China as seen in the flashbacks. But 3 Body Problem didnâ€™t really do that, and the seemingly limitless resources of the PDC/PIA were not really given a satisfactory explanation in-universe. Nor was it readily apparent why Wade was chosen to be in charge of Earthâ€™s defence against the San-Ti. Minor points, perhaps, in the context of the story. But you know me: I canâ€™t help nitpicking sometimes!

So that was 3 Body Problem. I had a fantastic time with the series; itâ€™s undoubtedly the best show Iâ€™ve seen in 2024 so far, and probably the best new sci-fi property that Iâ€™ve seen going back several years. My biggest fear right now is that it gets cancelled by Netflix before it can conclude its story, because that would be a real tragedy. 3 Body Problem is reportedly an expensive production, and Netflix has been very quick to swing the proverbial axe with shows and films that donâ€™t meet its sky-high expectations. So I admit that Iâ€™m worried about that.

With that significant caveat out of the way, however, I genuinely fell in love with this mysterious, grounded, and fascinating tale of humanityâ€™s first contact with a strange extraterrestrial race. I couldâ€™ve happily entertained another eight or ten episodes this season, digging even more deeply into this rich and complex story. Basing major plot points on real-world science, without resorting to fantastical technologies that are basically â€œspace magicâ€ kept 3 Body Problem feeling realistic and mature; grown-up sci-fi of the best kind.

I will be keeping my fingers crossed for that second-season renewal, and if Season 2 does get produced I hope youâ€™ll come back in 2025 or 2026 for my review! 3 Body Problem was great, and I highly recommend it.

3 Body Problem is available to stream now on Netflix. 3 Body Problem is the copyright of Netflix, The Three Body Universe, T-Street, and/or Plan B Entertainment. This review contains the thoughts and opinions of one person only and is not intended to cause any offence.

Spoiler Warning: There are spoilers ahead for Halo Seasons 1-2, and for the Halo video game series.

In 2022, I was one of the relatively small number of folks who enjoyed the first season of Halo. I didnâ€™t think it was the best thing since sliced bread or anything, but it felt like a decent adaptation of the long-running video game series â€“ albeit one that had been trimmed and cropped to fit a very specific mould used by other serialised streaming shows. Season 1 seemed to be a reasonable foundation upon which the next chapter of Halo could be built, so it was with some degree of anticipation that I awaited Season 2â€™s arrival.

And before we go any further, letâ€™s acknowledge just how long that wait actually was. Halo Season 1 ran from March to May 2022 â€“ meaning itâ€™s been basically two full years since it went off the air. And as Iâ€™ve noted in the past with other made-for-streaming shows like Amazonâ€™s The Wheel of Time, The Witcher on Netflix, or even some of the Star Trek shows on Haloâ€™s platform, Paramount+, there are issues that result from long breaks in between short seasons. I needed a recap before the first episode â€“ and at least in the UK, no such recap was forthcoming on Paramount+. Aside from the Master Chief and Kai, I couldnâ€™t remember who was who nor where exactly the story left off â€“ which wasnâ€™t helped by a time-jump of six months in-universe, in which characters had moved around and at least one major story beat had taken place off-screen.

Although it took me a while to get back into Halo during that first episode, as I was hampered by the lack of a proper recap, I will say that I did find myself engaging with the series as its story got going. Although I had to look up a plot synopsis for Season 1 online â€“ something I really shouldnâ€™t have needed to do â€“ once Iâ€™d got myself properly reacquainted with the main players, and recapped the major story beats from the end of Season 1, I found a story that was entertaining enough to justify paying for a monthâ€™s worth of Paramount+, and that I didnâ€™t mind following to its conclusion.

That being said, I still donâ€™t feel that Halo has truly excelled â€“ at least, not yet. Season 1 laid a solid foundation, but Season 2 seems to have disregarded parts of it, as well as deviated in a major way from the story that I remember from playing (most of) the main Halo video games. While Iâ€™m by no means a â€œcanon purist,â€ I have to wonder: why go to all the bother of licensing a major entertainment property only to jettison most of its story and some of its characters? The story of the Halo video games â€“ at least the first two or three titles, plus Halo: Reach â€“ would have made for a strong and captivating story in itself, and with only a few tweaks couldâ€™ve seen the addition of new characters to join the Master Chief.

In my review of the showâ€™s first season, I said that re-interpreting and changing the story â€“ and particularly finding a way to humanise the otherwise stoic Master Chief to make him into a sympathetic protagonist â€“ was something I was generally on board with. And I stand by that to a certain extent; I donâ€™t think a faceless, monotone character whoâ€™s an unfeeling killing machine would make for a good television protagonist, even if such a character works well in an action-heavy video game. But this time around, the Master Chiefâ€™s story felt muddled and seemed to rely on a few too many clichÃ©s and contrivances.

And partly, it must be noted, thatâ€™s because Haloâ€™s writers have now taken the story in a significantly different direction to its source material. In Season 1, with the Master Chief getting entangled with a Covenant agent, discovering his humanity, and unlocking the mysteries of a strange alien artefact, there was still the potential to call all of this a preamble; the hitherto-unseen prequel to more familiar events. But in Season 2, with the Fall of Reach being depicted on screen in a radically different way to how it unfolded in the games, and with the story more interested in the intrigue within the UNSC and ONI, that possibility has evaporated. Iâ€™m not sure whether the new story that the writers have replaced it with is as compelling or as entertaining as the one that was sitting there, waiting to be adapted.

There was clearly an ambition on the part of some of Haloâ€™s writers to use the UNSC, ONI, and the admiralty to look at the politics of war and the calculations that leaders have to make. This concept is sound, but it was let down by poor execution in Halo, unfortunately. In the first season, it felt as if most of the major characters â€“ including Keyes, Halsey, and Parangosky â€“ all had their own agendas. The Master Chief and his squad were caught in the crossfire and let down by the internal workings of the admiralty and leadership.

This message was somewhat streamlined in Season 2â€¦ but the way it was done necessitated some major contrivances. Corporal Perez, who Master Chief saved during the first episode of the series, refused to elaborate on what she saw of the Covenant during her debriefingâ€¦ for seemingly no reason other than â€œbecause plot,â€ and when her words would have corroborated what Master Chief reported, that just doesnâ€™t feel very satisfying. There was potential in Perezâ€™s story to look at trauma and in particular the post-traumatic stress that soldiers can suffer from â€“ but this angle was so undeveloped that Iâ€™m loathe to even include it as a plot point. In any case, it went nowhere â€“ and thus doesnâ€™t work as a justification for the narrative contrivance.

Perhaps this is the armchair general in me speakingâ€¦ but I have a hard time seeing a character like Ackerson as an out-and-out villain. When confronted with the reality that a Covenant attack was imminent and unstoppable, he and the other admirals took what seems the only rational path open to them: a covert, quiet evacuation of high-ranking personnel and valuable assets in order to establish a new command centre to continue the fight and co-ordinate the defence of other worlds. Reach was, as Cortana explained, already lost before the explosions started â€“ there was no way to prevent it.

Yet because weâ€™re following the story of Master Chief and his crew, the series paints Ackerson and Parangosky as antagonists â€“ more antagonistic, in some ways, than the Covenant themselves. And while we could entertain a more nuanced discussion of the â€œcalculus of warâ€ and how some leaders might try to use it as a justification to seize power or leave rivals for deadâ€¦ Halo doesnâ€™t really do any of that. It manoeuvres its characters into place â€“ using more than a couple of contrived moments to get them there â€“ and thenâ€¦ thatâ€™s it. Master Chief rages about how â€œthey stole [his] armourâ€ and his identity, but that just felt incidental and not like a driving force behind either the character or the story. The series came close to making a point about politics and war â€“ albeit one that other, stronger narratives have already made â€“ but then baulked on it at the last moment, despite the convoluted setup, in order to tee up the next big action sequence.

When such a story requires characters to act in a specific way to move things along, it can feel forced. And parts of Halo absolutely fall into this trap. During the climactic fight at Fleetcom, Master Chief and his Spartans are conveniently called away at the last second so they can be in just the right place to encounter Soren and Halsey, then Makee and the Arbiter, and finally to be rescued by Laera and Kwan. Master Chief was conveniently obscured by both fog and a communications blackout when he first encountered the Covenant, and the only other character to witness them refused to admit the truth. Laera was able to track down Soren just in time to save everyone from the attack on Reach. And so on.

Although Ackerson and Parangosky were manipulating the situation and keeping everyone in the dark about what was about to happen, their machinations canâ€™t account for all of this â€“ and the result is that the story is built on weak foundations. There are still successful moments of tension, excitement, and drama, and the deaths of major characters still manage to carry emotional weight. But that comes in spite of â€“ not because of â€“ the way in which the story has been structured. Halo is in real danger of getting in its own way.

In terms of visuals, Halo made a couple of missteps. Physical props used for things like spaceship doors, armour, and other pieces of supposedly â€œroughed-upâ€ metal could look pretty phony in places, and while it wasnâ€™t enough to take me out of the story entirely, it was definitely something I noticed across multiple episodes. This isnâ€™t something unique to Halo, as Iâ€™ve noted it in big-budget productions from Star Wars to the upcoming Fallout series, but that doesnâ€™t excuse it. Set design was generally okay, though, and I liked the interiors of the Covenant ships and the way they were laid out â€“ as well as how the show got creative with re-using certain sets for Makeeâ€™s ship, the training simulator, and a real Covenant ship in battle.

Halo had some successes with its CGI â€“ and one pretty epic misfire. The assault on Reach midway through the season, as well as the attack on another planet in the first episode, were fantastic, with explosions and plasma weapons that looked stunning. These were well-blended with physical sets, and the transitions between the two were great. The fleet battle toward the end of the season was likewise solid; a well-animated series of CGI sequences that lived up to the excitement I was hoping for from such a powerful narrative climax.

Then we got on the ground and came to the climactic one-on-one duel between Master Chief and his Covenant adversary, the Arbiter. The Arbiter felt vastly under-developed as a character, and while his hatred for the Master Chief was stated in almost every scene in which he appeared, there was no reciprocity there whatsoever, so the conflict itself felt very one-sided. I will say, though, that I liked the concept of this duel, and seeing plasma swords clashing almost like Jedi lightsabers was a fun idea, and a great way to take a rather clumsy weapon from the video game series and improve upon it. So in principle, this duel should have worked reasonably well.

But my god, the animation work here was atrocious.
